addressleaf.section:
To the right honorable my very singular good Lord
e L. Bur gh ley Lord highe Treasurer of England.

section.hand:
4 Julij 1592 M
r
bodeley fr
o
e Hage./

page.lettertext:
fol.75r
May it please yo
r
good L. w
t
muche deba-
ting and sending too and fro between the
Campe and
e Hage, it is finally concluded,
that
Count William
w
t
e forces of
Frise,
w
ch
I take to be 2500 and 10 other enseignes of
footemen, 8 or 10 cornets of horse, and 14 peeces
of batterie, shall ether take towardes
Coevoerden
in
Drente,
or make a roade to
e uttermost part
of
Twente,
w
ch
is
e contrey next adjoining,
and summon ether
Oldenzeel,
a garrison of
e
Enemie, in
e confines of Twente, southerly
from
steenwicke,
or
e castell of
Grolle,
w
ch
is likewise a place in
e Enemies possession,
standing south from
Zutphen
4 or 5 legues.
It is referred to Count William, as Governo
r
of Frise whom it most importeth, and to
e
Councel of estate
, to take
at course
at they
thinke fittest. The rest of
e Army are
left to
Count Maurice
conduction, to be im-
ploied in excursions, while Count William is
busied in
e siege of
e former places. How-
beit heere is very litle hope,
at ether of
the Countes will be able by this meanes to perfourme
any mater of speciall account. This is all
at
is conceaved,
at their late good successe against
e towne of steenwicke, w
t
e like before,
e
last yere, and their constant proceeding in
e
most of their exploites, will amase
e Enemie
so muche as happely he will yelde for feare
of
e
like
issue. But howsoever it shall happen, it
is resolved heere among
e states,
at about
e
first of August
e whole Army shall assemble
fol.75v
in a litle iland by
Bommel,
and likewise
at
e
forces w
ch
are expected out of
Juliers,
and their
troupes out of
France,
shall come to
e same place,
to give a soddaine attempt upon
e towne of
Bolduke,
w
ch
is a place of
at importance, as yo
r
L. hath heard, and by secret intelligence, w
ch
some
at are heere have had w
t
in
e towne, may
be gotten more easely, then most men would ima-
gine. This purpose of
e states is very
secretly caried, and not imparted out of Councel.
For
at
e winde is at
e Est, and puttes
me out of hope of hearing shortly from yo
r
L.
in her
Ma
ties
causes, and because
e states are
earnest w
t
me, to be present at
e campe w
t
e
Councel of estate, for
e effecting of their de-
signes, I will thitherwardes to morowe, and cer-
tifie from thens, as occasions are presented.
And so I take my humble leave. At
e Hage.
July 4 1592.
Yo
r
L. most humbly bounden Tho. Bodley
